comments.commentBody:
And how many Iraqi refugees has the US taken in after obliterating Iraq and producing at least 5 million Iraqi refugees? Do you know how many millions of Syrians and Iraqis are in Lebanon, Jordan, Turkey, and Iran?

Yes, the Saudis and the rest of the Gulf, who have destabilized Syria, must do more. But I find this American deflection so typical of our country which refuses to take responsibility for destabilizing the Middle East along with those Gulf allies. Before pointing fingers, look at yourself and what your government has done.

abo,

You are in France? Then you must know that the Libyan adventurer was instigated mostly by your former president so YOU are responsible for it.
really easy and really delicious.  Next time I will take someone else's suggestion and add cayenne pepper into the flour mixture.  (we added some Crystal at the table).

This is absolute rubbish. The US literally broke Iraq, murdered tens of thousands of people, destroyed its infrastructure, and dismantled a secular government, and now you blame it all on their "culture"? What about YOUR militaristic nation and its abhorrent culture?

Take responsibility for your nation's actions for once. You and your Saudi and Israeli allies have destabilized the region for decades.
Pre-9\11 Afghanistan ...... was considered ..... stable?!?
In case you missed, Yemen Iraq Libya Syria Afghanistan have already been bombed to death.

Cowards? Unpleasantness? Gee Fannie Mae, you live in a country that has historically welcomed immigrants arriving from countries escaping complicated civil wars such as Syria's. Sometimes escape is the only guarantee that your family will survive. This is a nasty, nasty, war that will last a long time. You are lucky that you live where you do. I don't think that you would eager to take on bombings, chemical weapons. And what side would you join? Assad? The jihadists? IS? As Jules said, your reality needs adjusting.

There have been a number of deaths in the Southwest in similar circumstances.  These are generally not big money operations -- $100 per person in one case in Texas.  As the article indicates, increased enforcement against those traveling by train encouraged truck travel between Hungary and Austria, which is particularly treacherous during the summer.  It appears that the truck driver abandoned his truck when he saw that many or all of his passengers had died.  The Texas truck driver who did the same was convicted of murder.  Without getting into broader issues, summer transport of people in the back of trucks must stop.  It seems to me that if you can check trucks for weight, you can check them for human cargo,  And if you only check them during the summer, the cost of enforcement should be reasonable.  The point isn't to solve the refugee problem.  It is to keep the refugees alive until the problem is solved.

This is a very sad and, more importantly, a very scary article.

I watched my brother, who drank himself to death at age 56, go through something similar at the end of his life. It was a relief when the doctor told us that we need to arrange hospice care for him. Even though he was basically unconscious the whole time in hospice, at least he was not uncomfortable and passed away peacefully.

I am very much hoping the state I live in, Callfornia, passes the assisted suicide law that has recently been introduced to the state legislature. As a cancer survivor, being able to voluntarily end my life rather than go through prolonged suffering is very important to me. It also seems like the humane thing to do, regardless of what Republican legislators and the Catholic Church think. After all, it is my life and my decision, not theirs.

The refugee crisis is caused by the toppling of regimes in the Middle East and Africa. It's cause and effect. We celebrate the the collapse of governments as pro-democracy movements in other countries with little thought as to how it can affect lives of people living there.

The rise of ISIS is a direct consequence of the toppling of Saddam Hussein. I was not a fan of his but I cannot believe that Iraqis are better off after our illegal invasion.

Want to stop the migrant crisis? Stop meddling in the Middle East and Africa.
Where on earth (pun intended) do you propose to create these new countries you speak of? Is there "undiscovered country" that you know of  that no-one else has discovered?

The global immigration crisis surely has met UN guidelines for a human disaster by now. So many people so desperate to leave their countries for whatever reason and so many countries not willing to take them or offer any realistic assistance. This is a pandemic and only the UN can handle this. Perhaps a new country or several countries need to be created to accommodate this diaspora.

Not realistic and really, from my stand as a strong opponent of the current system, not a good idea. Limiting weapons however is. You want to collect reptiles, fine. You want a cobra? No. You want to have 85 venemous snakes in your apartment? No.
You like pets? Fine. You want three cats? Fine. You have 17 cats in an apartment house? No. You want a couple of leopards and a wolf? No.
Now apply that to weapons and ammunition. Guns? Yes. Arsenals? Not without special permit.

Mr. Marshall the Australian Courts have ruled that there is no 1st Amendment like freedom of speech in Australia. So Australia is fundamentally a different type of nation than the US

And violent crime peaked after the gun ban was passed in Australia, while some forms of violent crime have since lowered and others have stabilized at rates not much different before the ban.

http://www.aic.gov.au/statistics/violent%20crime.html

@Susan Ahern.  "Vigilant, family members, co-workers and friends who witnessed the Virginia shooter's erratic behavior should have pressed for mental-health treatment for this Virginia journalist shooter."   Unless, the individual who is the object of your concern concurs with your assessment of his/her mental state and voluntarily submits to treatment, there is virtually nothing that you can do.  To have someone involuntarily subjected to treatment for mental or even life threatening physical conditions is extremely difficult. The first question that will be asked by those who have the authority to commit/incarcerate and/or mandate treatment will be "what has this individual DONE that poses a threat to the life and/or safety of himself or others?  Speculation--no matter how logical--about someone's future actions based on what has occurred or is now occurring with this person has no validity legally.  It is a frightening, frustrating, and painful circumstance to be an observer to what could become a tragic occurrence; but that often is your only recourse; I know from personal experience--wish I didn't.

I wish Mr. Parker great success in his new mission.  His job might be easier if we had responsible leaders in Washington who would do the right thing.  It's possible to protect second amendment rights yet have reasonable gun control laws, but our leaders cower when faced with the NRA and its rabid fanatics. Having daughters around the same age as the woman gunned down, I feel deeply for his loss.  Living in Denver, I also know what Columbine and theater massacres mean.  These are preventable, and should be prevented.

Of course we can't expect the individual nations of the EU to deal with this alone! Isn't this kind of thing one of the reasons why there's a European UNION?

Anyway, until actions are taken by the wealthy countries to help make the economies of the poorer countries more functional, this kind of thing will continue unabated. And by that I mean exactly NOT what Germany has done for Greece - DO NOT give them easy payday loans that help nothing and then demand repayment of those loans on punitive terms. Keep that up and there will be truckloads of dead Greeks appearing on the outskirts of Berlin.
Oh please give us some way to organize and shove the 2nd Amendment down the throats of the NRA.  I anm with you 100%.

These awful events will continue to occur as climate change worsens. There could be 100 million or more climate refugees in the coming decades.

There were supposedly 20 million climate refugees in 2008. Over the next few decades it has been estimated that there will be 200 million refugees, although no one knows until it happens. The Environmental Justice Foundation estimates 150 million in the next 35 years.
http://www.theguardian.com/environment/2009/nov/03/global-warming-climat...

http://www.bbc.com/news/magazine-23899195

http://www.dallasnews.com/opinion/sunday-commentary/20150724-michael-b.-...

"Perhaps President Bush, Vice President Cheney and other proponents of that fiasco might have the decency to chair the relief efforts." - What could possibly go wrong with THAT plan? Many entire shipping pallets of cash went missing in Iraq when they tried to fix that mess; I can't imagine letting those guys have an encore performance.

Eventually the countries affected by this tsunami of refugees from the Middle East will demand that we participate in defraying the cost of resettlement and providing refuge for these miserable people.  After all, our disastrous, misguided invasion of Iraq led directly to a good part of this problem. Perhaps President Bush, Vice President Cheney and other proponents of that fiasco might have the decency to chair the relief efforts.
Fortunately, the good people of the countries you cite don't see things the way you do.

Can you imagine the phrase Chicago, Wisconsin?
Originally the border of Wisconsin was supposed to go all the way to the south end of Lake Michigan. But Illinoisans knew that access to the lake was essential to developing commerce in their state and so they schemed to push the border north. Michigan's UP was also supposed to originally be part of Wisconsin. So poor Wisconsin lost out twice in terms of land.
In the near-furnace-like locked air-tight truck at the height of summer, of course they'd be in an advanced state of decomposition in little more than a day!
Your comment completely absolves tyrants like Syria's ruler and mass-movement thugs like Al Queda and ISIS.

What's S.A.D.?

Bacon and eggs.

and Elke
DL- S.A.D. =Samuel A. Donaldson.

Thanks R&E.

Actually, I figured that out not too long after I posted my question, and I posted an oops-never-mind comment.

It disappeared.

and Elke
I consider myself an omnivorous puzzler , i.e. can find something good in most puzzles. That said , I liked today's better than yesterday's. Mainly because the reveal was less than expected. Had it, but thought that there must be third layer.....Oh, well, did find out about BOHO-chic.

With today's S.A.D. did GET A HIT. Started in the NW and worked my way down. Had "stud" before HUNK. Banks not so much post CD RATES ,because they are approaching ZERO. Was thinking "footnotes" before ENDNOTES. Always a toss-up between AGORA s vs E...
Some moms ,when picking up their fallen tot, will say in addition to "YOU'RE OK", ask "WAIT , WHAT did you find while you were down there? A penny?"

Great clue for SON, worth the prize of admission. TED talks can be watched on-line for free.
Will Mac Knight link a picture of a LARK ? Have a great trip to OREgon's Coast, Mac. Get some fresh sea-air into your lungs.

It's always good to see PATENT next to VAS.
With that, good night.
Not so much like the Vikings, I think, but like the massive immigration (of Visigoths, Ostrogoths,  Huns, Vandals, and the like) which contributed to the fall of the Western Roman Empire.

Its like the Viking invasions I read about in the history books but instead of bloothirsty marauders seeking war, its the people fleeing them that are invading this time. The worst thing about this is probably not the plight of the syrians, (war always brings this sort of thing out) But the lack of skills the refugees have  and desire to leech off the richer European nations welfare. Its only a matter of time before this unrelenting horde overstrains the system and causes it to implode.
I find that Friday puzzles are hard after two vodkas. But after four they are easy.
Fogot to mention that City got a tough draw.

That's an interesting point. The low-skill, hard-labor jobs we have here really should go to our own people or our neighbors from the south, but most of the decent blue collar jobs we used to have have gone to Asia. Not as any kind of favor to Asian workers, but because they are more easily exploited.

The shame of all of this is that the vast majority of the migrants are economic migrants and the people that really need political refuge are stuck in Iraq or Syria and can't get out.  Since when are people from Albania and Lebanon political refugees or fleeing war.  Everyone that would never have  had a chance of legal migration to Europe is jumping on the boats. Europe is facing the same situation as the US - a huge influx of poor, low or no skilled and uneducated people who are seeking work.  The problem is that this is not the early 1900s and the factory jobs that absorbed the unskilled are long gone to Asia.  It really is an invasion.
